title: Colonial Era Quiz
description: How well do you recall the people and events of the colonial era?

questions.question: Which was the first permanent English settlement in North America, founded in 1607?
questions.explanation: Jamestown, Virginia was the first permanent English settlement in North America, established by the Virginia Company in 1607.

questions.question: Which ship brought the Pilgrims to Plymouth, Massachusetts in 1620?
questions.explanation: The Mayflower carried 102 passengers, known as Pilgrims, from England to Plymouth, Massachusetts, arriving in November 1620.

questions.question: What was the agreement for self-governance signed aboard the Mayflower?
questions.explanation: The Mayflower Compact, signed on November 11, 1620, was the first governing document of Plymouth Colony and an early step toward democratic self-governance.

questions.question: Which Native American woman helped the Jamestown settlers and married John Rolfe?
questions.explanation: Pocahontas, daughter of Chief Powhatan, helped bridge relations between the Powhatan people and Jamestown settlers and married colonist John Rolfe in 1614.

questions.question: Which event in 1773 was a protest against British taxation of tea?
questions.explanation: The Boston Tea Party on December 16, 1773, saw colonists dump 342 chests of tea into Boston Harbor to protest the Tea Act's taxation without representation.

questions.question: Who founded the colony of Pennsylvania as a haven for Quakers?
questions.explanation: William Penn founded Pennsylvania in 1681 as a Quaker colony that promoted religious freedom and peaceful relations with Native Americans.

questions.question: Which colony was founded by Roger Williams after he was expelled from Massachusetts for his religious views?
questions.explanation: Roger Williams founded Rhode Island in 1636, establishing it as a colony with complete religious freedom and separation of church and state.

questions.question: What was the series of witch trials held in Massachusetts in 1692?
questions.explanation: The Salem Witch Trials of 1692 resulted in the execution of 20 people, becoming one of the most infamous episodes of mass hysteria in American history.

questions.question: Which crop became the economic foundation of the Jamestown colony?
questions.explanation: Tobacco, cultivated by John Rolfe beginning around 1612, became Jamestown's cash crop and the economic foundation of colonial Virginia.

questions.question: What was the 1765 act that imposed direct taxes on the American colonies for the first time?
questions.explanation: The Stamp Act of 1765 required colonists to pay a tax on printed materials, sparking widespread protests and the cry of 'No taxation without representation.'

questions.question: Which colonial leader helped establish the city of Savannah and the colony of Georgia?
questions.explanation: James Oglethorpe founded the colony of Georgia in 1733, originally intended as a haven for debtors and a buffer against Spanish Florida.

questions.question: Which 1770 event saw British soldiers kill five colonists in Boston?
questions.explanation: The Boston Massacre occurred on March 5, 1770, when British soldiers fired into a crowd of colonists, killing five men. It became a rallying point for independence.

questions.question: What was the first representative assembly in the American colonies, established in 1619?
questions.explanation: The House of Burgesses was established in Jamestown, Virginia in 1619 as the first representative legislative assembly in the American colonies.

questions.question: Which war between the French and British (1754-1763) determined colonial control of North America?
questions.explanation: The French and Indian War (Seven Years' War in Europe) ended with Britain gaining control of French territories in North America through the Treaty of Paris in 1763.

questions.question: How many original colonies declared independence from Britain in 1776?
questions.explanation: Thirteen colonies declared independence from Britain on July 4, 1776, forming the United States of America.
